trans-unit.source: Convert to CSV
trans-unit.target: Convert to CSV

trans-unit.source: Converts data input to a comma-separated values format
trans-unit.target: Converts data input to a comma-separated values format

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="D1293C4F-5629-4EEF-90A4-097AF6945ED6" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Format Conversions</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="D1293C4F-5629-4EEF-90A4-097AF6945ED6" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Format Conversions</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module to convert any dataset used by modules in Azure Machine Learning to a comma-separated value (CSV) file.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module to convert any dataset used by modules in Azure Machine Learning to a comma-separated value (CSV) file.

trans-unit.source: This type of conversion is useful in many scenarios:
trans-unit.target: This type of conversion is useful in many scenarios:

trans-unit.source: The CSV format is one of the main formats used by the R language.
trans-unit.target: The CSV format is one of the main formats used by the R language.

trans-unit.source: CSV files can be easily imported to Excel and relational databases.
trans-unit.target: CSV files can be easily imported to Excel and relational databases.

trans-unit.source: You can save interim results to the CSV format to download or to present in visualizations created by tools such as Excel or Power View.
trans-unit.target: You can save interim results to the CSV format to download or to present in visualizations created by tools such as Excel or Power View.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Binary Classification sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink> exports the results of cross validation to the CSV format, so that results for multiple models can be compared by using a tool such as Excel.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Binary Classification sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink> exports the results of cross validation to the CSV format, so that results for multiple models can be compared by using a tool such as Excel.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Color Quantization sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525272</linkUri></externalLink> exports the datasets used for each portion of the analysis to CSV files, so that you can easily run a similar model in any tool that supports CSV.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Color Quantization sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525272</linkUri></externalLink> exports the datasets used for each portion of the analysis to CSV files, so that you can easily run a similar model in any tool that supports CSV.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: The CSV file format is variously referred to “comma-separated values” or “character-separated values.”
trans-unit.target: The CSV file format is variously referred to “comma-separated values” or “character-separated values.”

trans-unit.source: Excel (.xls, .xlsx) files can be easily exported into CSV files.
trans-unit.target: Excel (.xls, .xlsx) files can be easily exported into CSV files.

trans-unit.source: A CSV file stores tabular data (numbers and text) in plain text form.
trans-unit.target: A CSV file stores tabular data (numbers and text) in plain text form.

trans-unit.source: A CSV file consists of any number of records, separated by line breaks of some kind.
trans-unit.target: A CSV file consists of any number of records, separated by line breaks of some kind.

trans-unit.source: Each record consists of fields, separated by some other character or string—most commonly a literal comma or tab.
trans-unit.target: Each record consists of fields, separated by some other character or string—most commonly a literal comma or tab.

trans-unit.source: Typically, all records have an identical sequence of fields with missing values incorporated as NULL (no data).
trans-unit.target: Typically, all records have an identical sequence of fields with missing values incorporated as NULL (no data).

trans-unit.source: Note the following requirements for the CSV file format provided in Azure Machine Learning:
trans-unit.target: Note the following requirements for the CSV file format provided in Azure Machine Learning:

trans-unit.source: This CSV file format supports a single header row.
trans-unit.target: This CSV file format supports a single header row.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module does not support the use of alternative column separators, such as the semicolon (;), which is often used in Europe.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module does not support the use of alternative column separators, such as the semicolon (;), which is often used in Europe.

trans-unit.source: However, when you use the <link xlink:href="4e1b0fe6-aded-4b3f-a36f-39b8862b9004" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Reader</link> module to get data from CSV files in external storage, you can now specify alternative separators by selecting the <ui>CSV with encodings</ui> option.
trans-unit.target: However, when you use the <link xlink:href="4e1b0fe6-aded-4b3f-a36f-39b8862b9004" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Reader</link> module to get data from CSV files in external storage, you can now specify alternative separators by selecting the <ui>CSV with encodings</ui> option.

trans-unit.source: If you export a column of string data that contains commas, no special handling is performed, such as enclosing strings in quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: If you export a column of string data that contains commas, no special handling is performed, such as enclosing strings in quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: Moreover, you cannot use escape characters before a comma to ensure that commas are handled as a literal character.
trans-unit.target: Moreover, you cannot use escape characters before a comma to ensure that commas are handled as a literal character.

trans-unit.source: As a result, new fields are created in the output file for each comma.
trans-unit.target: As a result, new fields are created in the output file for each comma.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module supports only UTF-8 character encoding.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Convert to CSV</ui> module supports only UTF-8 character encoding.

trans-unit.source: If the dataset you are exporting to a CSV file does not have column names, you can use <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> to add column names before converting it.
trans-unit.target: If the dataset you are exporting to a CSV file does not have column names, you can use <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> to add column names before converting it.
